skill.name: worldview-synthesis
skill.description: This skill should be used when someone wants to articulate, explore, or document their personal worldview, values, or philosophy. Triggers on "articulate my values", "figure out what I believe", "document my philosophy", "write a manifesto", "define my leadership philosophy", "explore my beliefs". Surfaces beliefs through systematic interrogation, identifies tensions, and generates narrative outputs.

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only documentation, methodology instructions, and philosophical questioning templates. No executable code, file access, network calls, or external command execution. All 62 static findings are false positives: YAML type annotations and markdown syntax were misidentified as cryptographic code and shell commands. The skill is fundamentally a personal reflection tool with no security implications.

content.user_title: Explore and articulate your personal worldview
content.value_statement: People struggle to clearly express their core beliefs, values, and contradictions. This skill guides users through systematic questioning across 20 life domains to surface hidden assumptions, identify productive paradoxes, and generate shareable narratives from mission statements to full essays.
actual_capabilities: Guide users through 6 rounds of structured questions across 20 life domains
Identify tensions and productive paradoxes in personal beliefs
Generate narratives at ascending scales from mission statements to full essays
Apply YAML schema to organize beliefs as a structured knowledge graph
Provide ready-to-use interrogation questions for systematic self-reflection
Help users distinguish between hard ethical lines and softer truths
limitations: Does not execute code or access files on your system
Does not connect to external APIs or services
Output quality depends on user engagement and honest self-reflection
Cannot replace therapy or professional guidance for deep psychological work

use_cases.title: Define leadership philosophy
use_cases.description: Articulate core values to shape team culture and create consistent decision-making frameworks

use_cases.title: Write authentic manifestos
use_cases.description: Create mission statements and manifestos that sound genuinely like you, not generic platitudes

use_cases.title: Clarify company values
use_cases.description: Document personal beliefs that should shape company culture, ethics, and hiring practices

prompt_templates.title: Quick values check
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me quickly identify my top 5 core values using the AskUserQuestion tool with 2 options each.

prompt_templates.title: Full exploration
prompt_templates.prompt: Guide me through a complete worldview synthesis session. Start by asking about my influences, then run 4-6 rounds of interrogation questions, capture tensions, and generate a mission statement.

prompt_templates.title: Company values
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me articulate my personal values to define company culture. Use questions about leadership, ethics, and decision-making to extract my core beliefs.

prompt_templates.title: Tension surfacing
prompt_templates.prompt: Run interrogation rounds focused on money, competition, trust, and conflict. Help me identify where my beliefs contradict each other and name those tensions clearly.

output_examples.input: Help me articulate my values and write a personal mission statement
output: Core Thesis: One sentence capturing your fundamental worldview
Mission Statement: 100 words with 5-7 guiding principles
Key Tensions: 3-5 productive paradoxes you embrace
Hard Lines: Non-negotiable ethical boundaries you refuse to cross
Softer Truths: Areas where you extend grace and allow nuance

output_examples.input: I want to figure out what I actually believe about success
output: Success Definition: How you measure achievement and meaning
Influences: Books, people, and experiences that shaped this view
Tensions: Where your success beliefs conflict with other values
Narrative: A short essay connecting your beliefs into coherent story

output_examples.input: Help me prepare to write a company handbook
output: Leadership Philosophy: How you lead and why
Decision Framework: Principles for hard choices
Culture Values: What behaviors you reward and discourage
Ethical Boundaries: Where you will not compromise regardless of cost

best_practices: Start with sources (books, people, experiences) before diving into direct questions about beliefs
Push past comfort zones to explore death, money, conflict, and ethics directly
Name tensions explicitly rather than trying to resolve contradictions away
anti_patterns: Accepting vague should beliefs without probing for actual behavior and real actions
Allowing users to claim they have no worldview (everyone has one, even if unexamined)
Resolving tensions instead of naming and embracing productive paradoxes as authentic

faq.question: What AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Works with Claude, Codex, and Claude Code for structured reflection sessions using the AskUserQuestion tool.

faq.question: How long does a full session take?
faq.answer: A complete worldview synthesis takes 60-90 minutes including 4-6 interrogation rounds across 20 life domains.

faq.question: Can I use this for team alignment?
faq.answer: Yes, run individual sessions and compare outputs to find common values and productive tensions across team members.

faq.question: Is my data stored anywhere?
faq.answer: No, this skill only provides prompts and structure. Your answers stay in the conversation and are not stored externally.

faq.question: Why are tensions important?
faq.answer: Tensions reveal where you hold multiple valid truths simultaneously. They make your worldview authentic rather than oversimplified.

faq.question: How is this different from regular values exercises?
faq.answer: It treats worldview as a graph with tensions, not a flat list of values. It explicitly surfaces and names contradictions.
